title: YiZhan/JJRC X6 body-15º rise arms-anti Vibe Mount

description.text:
••Updated March 13th 2016••
New unit is named with "PINNED" in the title. and if you look at the model the front is marked only with a Single letter "F" on the new one. Old one has the word "FRONT" on the face. Also the correct one has no knock outs in the anti vibe arms as it's a good bit shorter.••• Now has centering pins for the FC board and padding to line up easier like the stock Tarantula body does. OK... one more step done. Added a Pre-attached Anti Vibe Plate. Should match right up to the WLtoys V262 style anti vibe balls and lower plate to hold battery and camera. YiZhan/JJRC X6 tarantula studs for FC Board so no grinding out to match the WLtoys setup. Will need angle arms to bring the sticks back to level from the 15º rise.
Cut Stock WLToys carbon stick arms.. slide in body, slide in angle bracket.. other 1/2 of stick in bracket then the motor mount. The Anti Vibe DOES have a front/back and sides difference.. reason there is now a marked front. Use the stock balls/balloons from a WLtoys "V" series camera mount as well as the bottom plate. LET ME KNOW IF YOU PRINT ONE! especially if there are issues in lineup and fitting. Got to give credit to all the folks over at the Sketchup forums for all the help getting this done!! Next comes legs....

title: Laptop Cart Clip (Fits Standard Laptop Cords)

description.text: I realized our school had a problem! When students remove laptops from computer carts, the cords turn into a mess worse than an unrolled spool of filament! I designed this which attaches to each shelf on the cart and allows a standard laptop cord to clip onto it. This traps the cord and keeps all of the cords organized and looking nice. You could even print each cart's clips in a different color of Makerbot PLA to know which clips go which which carts. This helped solve a cord problem at my school, so it should at your school too! This was designed in Tinkercad and 3D printed to test the reliability of it. I will be attaching pictures soon! Thank you so much!

description.header: Learning Animation Physics with a Zoetrope
description.text:
Objectives Learn how animation works by using a 19th-century zoetrope device.
Learn how customizing the Zoetrope device changes the experience of the animation
Learn how code can be used to design an object Audience Grades 3-7 Preparation
  • Print a zoetrope using the STL or 3MF file
  • Print Zoetrope strips found on the internet (https://www.bing.com/images/search?q=zoetrope%20strip&qs=n&form=QBIR&pq=zoetrope%20strip&sc=7-14&sp=-1&sk=)
    • Steps
  • Cut out Zoetrope strips and try them out in pre-printed zoetrope devices
  • Spray-paint a light-colored zoetrope with black spraypaint to see if it affects the results
  • Color/draw your own Zoetrope strips
  • Print your own zoetrope devices
  • customize zoetrope devices to see how changing the size, slit width, number of slits,changes the animation
    • Results Students have their own Zoetrope devices and animation strips that they can share and can find and create their own strips to go with their devices.

In Invent to Learn (http://inventtolearn.com/), Martinez and Stager site 3-D printing as one of the three most powerful tools to help transform education with the Maker Movement in mind. However, they do warn against the “Yoda keychain” phenomenon, in which students use this technology to simply make infinite copies of a trinket (such as a Yoda keychain) instead of benefiting from learning the power of design when paired with desktop fabrication. This lesson merges language arts and technology (and keychains!), to add a third dimension to your students' next book report that would garner admiration from even the wisest of Jedi masters.
I created the basic keychain on Tinkercad, and that file is available publicly. (https://goo.gl/FWLH8T) and the key can be found here (https://tinkercad.com/things/20NL1tXoi9G).
CCSS

Book reports are nearly as old as books! Okay, not quite, but you get the picture- book reports, while a tried and true way to encourage students express their comprehension of a recently completed text are a bit dated. With this lesson you still give students the chance to reflect on their book, but also build design skills. Objectives:
Students will design and print three keychains, one for each of three different characters from a recently read book. Each keychain must possess one or more elements that describe that character's personality, motivations, challenges, or important relationships in the story. In the process, they will also gain skills and knowledge in 3-D design and fabrication. Audience:
This lesson is intended for fourth/fifth grade and up, but could be modified for younger students with support (e.g. the teacher could design a single set of keychains based on student input). Subjects:
Reading comprehension
Design Skills Learned (Standards):
CCSS ELA: (Fourth Grade) RL.4.2, RL.4.3 (Fifth Grade) RL.5.2, RL.5.3

Step 1 After completing a book students consider three characters they wish to focus on. Journals, essays, graphic organizers, collages, etc., are a great way for students to consider the traits and motivations of those characters they wish to feature in their designs. Step 2 Introduce students to Tinkercad, allowing them time for free exploration and/or to complete tutorials. Step 3 Next, students design three keychains, one for each of their selected characters. As time and resources allow, encourage students to iterate- design, fabricate, re-design, fabricate- until their keychains are ready for display. Step 4 If possible, have students share their completed keychains alongside written works, or other supporting materials, in the classroom or around school for other students to enjoy. Step 5 As an extension, have students create a small set of keys to accompany each keychain. Each key can list an additional trait which defines that character.
3-5 sessions
This project should be completed following reading a chapter book, either as a class or individually.

Here is a concise reminder of the importance of building strong reading comprehension (http://www.k12reader.com/the-importance-of-reading-comprehension/) Rubric & Assessment See the suggested rubric above to assess students on both story/character elements included and design. Handouts & Assets Looking for some graphic organizers to help your students structure their thoughts prior to design? Scholastic has you covered! (http://www.scholastic.com/teachers/top-teaching/2013/01/reading-response-forms-and-graphic-organizers)

remixed_from.author: Buback
remixed_from.title: Helical Crayford Focuser for Newtonian Telescope

description.text: This Focuser is adjustable, in that you can use various diameter focuser tubes (within a certain range). It can be tough to source the proper sized tube in short lengths in a cost effective way, so this design allows you to use what you can find locally. Probably the best source is PVC tubing. A zip tie is used to close the 'petals' onto the tube. Perhaps you can use a large rubber band as well, which would be a bit better for instances where the tube isn't consistent in OD. Maybe one of those silicon bracelets? A large hose clamp could also work. Half of the bearings are also inverted. This moves the bearings into two planes, so that it only moves along one axis and doesn't tilt to the sides. In v1 this was done with steps, but I think this design is cleaner. One revolution yields about 35 mm of travel with the standard petals, which have a 15 degree angle. The fine petals have a 5 degree angle, and I assume should be ~11.5 mm/revolution. All the sketchup files are in the zip below. Add a comment if there's any trouble opening it. Video: http://youtu.be/bW7UEPq3LA8

Print 6 petals, 1 Focuser base, and an eyepiece lock (which you might want to redesign to fit your tube, so source your tube first). 
Assemble as in the pictures, except use smaller screws :-). Everything is M4 except the M3 on the eyepiece screws. I think m4x30 is a bit conservative, and you might be able to use smaller, like 20-25mm. In the pictures of mine, i used 40mm 'cause that's what i have on hand, but there's at least 15-20mm extra.
You might also like a focus tube lock, and if so print out one lock petal and only 5 petals, replacing the 6th petal with the lock petal (only in the fine pitch for now)
There is a base plate for a 6 inch tube like a PVC drainage tube, and one for a truss like design, which has a flat bottom face. The truss base plate is more multipurpose; it can be used on all sized telescope tubes and trusses. You just need to print an adapter to attach it to, so i would recommend the truss design.

These are a direct replacement for the equivalent parts from the shoulder assembly. This derivative beefs up the shoulder frame by adding the following features:
  • increases pivconnector width to 10mm
  • increases rotmit and rottit mounts to 10mm
  • countersunk mount holes to reinforce subassembly
  • round pivconnector features
    • Print these out with any layer height you'd like, I generally go with 250 micron layers.
  • 6-8 perimeters
  • 2mm tops and bottoms
  • 15% infill
    • To Assemble:

  • Drill and countersink all parts for #8 screws.

  • Start with PivTit. Attach PivConnectors and screw into place.
  • Attach PivTit to worm gear subassembly
  • Slide PivMit into shoulder subassembly, screw into place
    • Also I didn't recreate RotMit and RotTit, they're just modified from the original files.
    RotMit rear mount is about 1mm off from center. I couldn't correct this without recreating the part. When I get caught up on other things I may come back and fix it correctly. Updates:
  • 2016-02-27 Updated PivMit, increased clearance between PivMit and PivTit so it's easier to slide PivMit into position.
  • 2016-02-25 Updated PivMit to V3, added small recess to allow PivMit to slide into subassembly. Added instructions

title: Proving the Earth is round. How round you ask? Print this and find out.

description.text:
I wanted to make something that I could show my daughter (due in 8 weeks) how we learned long ago that our planet was round. This is a small model to help conceptualize this fact. I've placed the sticks in the approximate locations of Eratosthenes' points of measurement. This was also my first time using Tinkercad and my M3D Micro printer. I hope you have fun using this little thing to help prove our planet is round! Eratosthenes calculated the circumference of the Earth without leaving Egypt. Eratosthenes knew that at local noon on the summer solstice in the Ancient Egyptian city of Swenet (known in ancient Greek as Syene, and now as Aswan) on the Tropic of Cancer, the Sun would appear at the zenith, directly overhead. He knew this because he had been told that the shadow of someone looking down a deep well in Syene would block the reflection of the Sun at noon off the water at the bottom of the well. Using a gnomon, he measured the Sun's angle of elevation at noon on the solstice in Alexandria, and found it to be 1/50th of a circle (7°12') south of the zenith. He may have used a compass to measure the angle of the shadow cast by the Sun. Assuming that the Earth was spherical (360°), and that Alexandria was due north of Syene, he concluded that the meridian arc distance from Alexandria to Syene must therefore be 1/50th of a circle's circumference, or 7°12'/360°. His knowledge of the size of Egypt was founded on the work of many generations of surveying trips. Pharaonic bookkeepers gave a distance between Swenet and Alexandria of 5,000 stadia (a figure that was checked yearly). Some say this distance was corroborated by inquiring about the time that it took to travel from Syene to Alexandria by camel. Carl Sagan says that Eratosthenes paid a man to walk and measure the distance. Some claim Eratosthenes used the Olympic stade of 176.4 meters, which would imply a circumference of 44,100 km, an error of 10%, but the 184.8 meter Italian stade became (300 years later) the most commonly accepted value for the length of the stade, which implies a circumference of 46,100 km, an error of 15%. It was unlikely, even accounting for his extremely primitive measuring tools, that Eratosthenes could have calculated an accurate measurement for the circumference of the Earth due to three important assumptions he made (none of which are perfectly accurate): That Alexandria and Syene lay on the same meridian,
That the distance between Alexandria and Syene was 5000 stades,
That the Earth was a perfect sphere.
Eratosthenes later rounded the result to a final value of 700 stadia per degree, which implies a circumference of 252,000 stadia, likely for reasons of calculation simplicity as this larger number is evenly divisible by sixty.[17] Repeating Eratosthenes' calculation with more accurate data, the result is 40,074 km, which is 66 km different (0.16%) from the currently accepted polar circumference of the Earth. Seventeen hundred years after Eratosthenes' death, while Christopher Columbus studied what Eratosthenes had written about the size of the Earth, he chose to believe, based on a map by Toscanelli, that the Earth's circumference was one-third smaller. Had Columbus set sail knowing that Eratosthenes' larger circumference value was more accurate, he would have known that the place where he made landfall was not Asia, but rather a New World.
Source: Wikipedia- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eratosthenes#Measurement_of_the_Earth.27s_circumference

author: arapine

description.text:
I lost the plate for my tripod, that holds the screw for the camera. So I made another one.
Even if you don't loose it, it's always nice to have multiple plates, one for each camera !
I used these screws : http://www.ebay.com/itm/141737493634 You can easily adjust the OpenSCAD file for other screws. You may have to adjust some dimensions, everything is a tight fit and it's linked to your printer calibration. There is no lock washer, the screw is force-fitted in place so it doesn't fall unless you unscrew it yourself (however the OpenSCAD file has provisions for a lock washer if you can/want to print with support). There is a self-centering bevel on the back so that when you screw the screw into the camera, the screw should self center. Use a 0.1mm print height so that the self-centering bevel is as smooth as possible. I do not have the model number for my tripod, so I attached a picture.
It's very likely that you can adjust the OpenSCAD model for other tripods too. If you do so, make sure to upload a remix ! :) Code is not the cleanest - but it does the job. There is also a nice roundedCube module for rounded edge cubes. It compensates for the additional size added by the Minkowski transform used, something I rarely see. Pretty handy. I also designed replacement feet for the same tripod :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1284763

remixed_from.title: Boscam RX-LCD5802 FPV Monitor Mount for Spektrum DX6 Transmitter

title: Case for Taranis based Camera Controller v1.1

description.text:
I decided to create a complete new Housing to control the Gimbal for a Drone. I wanted a customized housing for the special needs of a camera operator.
The topplate is laser cutted and made out of wood or POM. I recommend POM for the look and feel. Some parts I created/remixed to use with this housing:
FPV Camera Mount to have a secondary small cam underneath the Gimbal Attachement of the payload. In case of slow motion recording or different camera is attached: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1343766 A Boscam 5802 Mount to attach the screen directly to the Housing and internal Powersupply is also included. This is a remix from Thing 1069007 Added also some parts of my other designs as they were designed to use in this project (FPV camera mount for Sony RX 100 IV and a servo mount as well to remote control manual focus).
Due to the assembling phase I recognized the orignial bottons of the Taranis weren't quite useful. So I designed some new which will fit perfectly into the cutted holes of the topplate and have a nice feeling when using it. I used a Lasercutter to create the Topplate. It is made out of POM. Any other material like ply wood or acrylic glas will work as well. I engraved the Plate and painted it a bit to increase the contrast of the letters. Note: Due to printing my housing had a few deformations. So I adjusted the top plate for a perfect match again. Thw top plate will be uploaded in EPS format So you can adjust it as you want and as you need. Some more information (in german) about the project : http://fpv-community.de/showthread.php?72904-Kamera-und-Gimabl-Steuerung-auf-Basis-von-Taranis I added an expansion port and controller. For the axpansion controller I added a different thing. Please see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1832030 Note: This is work in progress. I will update this thing.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100% (to maximize stability)

Notes: I printed the housing from bottom to top with an infill of 100%. Before I tried with 15% (just to save time and it felt stable) but it broke apart after a few months. It broke because of the weight of the screen. The screws are noe more loose and just hold the screen in place. Additionally I attached a wooden support which will hold the screen as well is support for a neck strap. Beside these tasks it is also the first point touching the ground. It so prevent the case from cracks when putting away (a bit more rough). Just want to have is as durable as possible as I want to use it and don't want to think about if it could fell apart.
Changed position of Antenna Mount. Otherwise you have to re-solder your antenna (as me) as it cable is to short to reach the other side.
Changed Thickness of mounting holes to increas durability I had some trouble printing the battery cover as it broke all the time as the layers were in the wrong orientation for the force. So I decided to print it upright. I uploaded a special stl with a thin 0.1 mm think shell on the top. You need to remove it, I added it just to make it printable and force the printer to add support. Otherwise I'm afraid it will fall over while printing. But it worked out well. I updated the mounting plate for the Boscam Screen as well. it broke appart. I designed it stronger now and printed it with 100% infill. Guess now the housing is the weaker part but the mounting plate is strong as I wanted it ;) There are two different faceplates. One is dedicated to use a small compact style camera like Sony RX100. The other one is designed for Black Magic Micro. I had a Sony before but switched to the Black Magic during the process.
In the EPS Files you will find also some spare designs for internal parts as placeholder as well as placeholders for switches I used.
Additionally I have there some leftover designs from former switches. Maybe use ful for somebody (like six position switch) Added layout for the wooden support. Not much to mention here. This was the part I developed/tuned less. So it will fit but not 100% perfectly. There are some gaps of around 1-2 mm, but it will do its job. I cutted it from 5 mm plywood. The big holes are designed to use bigger antennas. Added an extension port (one switch/channel isn't used yet), I want to have it accessible from outside as well as the trainer port. It would be great to have some expansion controllers for different tasks, features, payloads (for example motion tracking or combined auto focus and shutter release for photo cameras)
The expansion port will use Sub-D 15 Connector.
Please see the link for more details:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1832030

description.text: Watch a bearded dragon eat crickets for a few minutes and imagine them as knights and princesses and you get a pretty good idea of what an actual dragon would be like. A little short on the flying and fire breathing, but plenty scary nonetheless. One advantage to reptiles as pets (some would argue the only advantage) is that they spend a lot of time doing nothing which makes them the ideal pet for photo scanning. While Rex the bearded dragon stared with her beady reptile eyes I shot 53 photos. The results were processed with Agisoft and reworked a bit with 3dCoat to make them printable. We talked about this and a whole lot more on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio learn more at http://www.threedprintingtoday.com/

title: The "Revolver" - One Colour Print version of this Challenging Revolving Puzzle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The "Revolver" is a 3D printed puzzle with 41 independent moving parts that revolve / slide around a two part Retainer. The prints are all easy and straight forward and the result is really impressive... This is an alternative to the 6 colour version that features shapes that need to be grouped to solve the puzzle instead of grouping colours. This will suit people without enough filament colours or who don't want to go to the trouble to make it colorful. Refer to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1341294 to view the colour version. This is similar to a Rubik's cube in that the aim is to align / group matching shapes but there are two puzzles in one with the Revolver as you can align rows or columns to have all the same shapes in a line. One space is left to allow for the Sliders to move one space at a time. This means you need to plan your moves as you move towards your goal... of course you can pull it apart if you get frustrated with it and realign it that way but if you're really up for the challenge glue the thread so it will never come apart! The parts are all easy prints and assemble is very straight forward. This 'shape' version does not need different filament colors like the 6 colour slider version . The images provided creates a great result. Black is used for the Retainer. All Revolvers and the Sliders are best printed in the same colour. As you need to leave one Slider out to make a space for movement it is recommended to leave out one of the vertical bar sliders ( | ) as the slot in the underlying Revolver looks similar so the empty space / gap is less noticeable (Refer to images for additional information). To achieve the end result does take time but it's well worth the effort. Print each .stl separately (Retainer / Revolvers / Sliders). Most machines capable of printing fine detail and good slicing apps should have no problem with the fine tolerances in this print.
Watching it come together is satisfying... once it's together, and with the Slider shapes well messed up, it can be very frustrating... until you solve it and then it's very satisfying again! Print the puzzle... then see if you can you do it? And, if you do... post images of your success! Please refer to the print instructions and images for additional information. A zip file has been added with all of the slider files so they can be printed individually if necessary. Note: If you like this check out all my other fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard in PLA

Infill:

3 Shells / 35% Infill for the Retainer file. The Revolvers and Sliders can be 2 Shells and 20% Infill

Notes: Easy prints however the 'Retainer' file needs to be printed with 3 shells / 35% infill to ensure it is strong enough when screwed together. The other parts (Revolvers and Sliders) can be printed with 2 Shells / 20% infill as they don't need to be as strong. Note: Most accurate machines / good slicing apps should have no problems with these files however the tolerances are fine so other less accurate machines may not slide / rotate as easily or screw together easily. This has been tested on a Replicator 2 and 5th Generation Replicator with great results.

Assembly required... but it's quick and easy! Remove the Raft then assemble the Sliders into the Revolvers. Make sure they all move freely / smoothly as the Sliders need to be able to move from Revolver to Revolver to solve the puzzle. One Revolver needs to be left with only 5 of 6 spaces filled (i.e. leave one out) as a space is required to allow you to move the sliders around one space at a time. This is what makes it challenging... like a Rubik's cube but round with rotating / sliding parts. Once the Revolvers / Sliders are assembled carefully place them onto the long part of the retainer. Once all are in place screw the second part of the Retainer (with the thread protruding) into the assembled Retainer / Revolvers / Sliders.. You only need to make it finger tight as you may need to unscrew it later if you can't solve it... although try not to cheat! You can glue the thread so it will never come undone if you are up for the challenge... Please refer to the images provided for additional information. A zip file has been added with all of the slider files so they can be printed individually if necessary. QUICK TIP: As you need to leave one Slider out to make a space for movement it is recommended to leave out one of the vertical bar sliders ( | ) as the slot in the underlying Revolver looks similar to the slider. This make sthe empty space / gap less noticeable.

comments.text:
This is a cool "thing". For those of you wanting a single model to print rather than a group... If you are using KisSlicer load the STL up onto the build plate with all 6 sliders. Then click the extruder mapping windows in the upper right corner. These are the windows that show a small graphic of what is on the bed to be printed. When you do this a mapping screen will appear. You will see that there is a mesh line for each of the 6 pieces on the build plate. Click each of them that you don't want to print and then select void. You will have to void each of the items separately. The line on the mapping screen will show which ones are void. Now when you do the slice only the remaining pieces will actually be sliced and put in the g-code file. There is a downside to this if you use a raft. The raft will be big enough for all 6 parts regardless of how many you void. I don't know how you would do this with Slic3r but there may be a way.
Bob

this is something i've been trying to pull off for a while, to do a mash-up taking some pre-made parts like a car body, wheels, engine, and combine them into one solid object... for a CARtoons Magazine, CARtoony look, this was harder than I thought (lack of 3D skills)... putting all the pieces together was no big deal... making it a solid that can be print, not so much... anyway... Plate to cover the access hole on a Festool TS-75 track saw to improve dust collection.  The plate simply snaps in place to block the blade access hole in the side of the saw.  When printed, you will need to do a little fine tuning (filing/sanding) of the front and back edges of the plate that insert into the opening to achieve a perfect fit.  Please note that the casting on the front edge of the opening in the saw is slightly thinner than the back edge.  The cover plate is designed to match this so you just need to be careful to insert the cover plate in the correct orientation.

title: Print challenge: Can you print the ball?

description.text:
Funny test for your 3d printing skills: Can you print the ball? Layer: 0.2 or 0.3 (quality does not matter)
Perimeters: 2 or 3
Support: No
Infill: 0%
Brim: 10 turns max
Raft: no
Top and Bottom Layers: 2 PS: Print in the current position, rotations not allowed :-)
Other settings: free to change... Current photos: Done!

description.text: This is the design of a sustainable future city that provides energy to its citizens by using nuclear reactors. This design was accomplished by one one of my students in class based on my lessons on how to model 3D buildings with Tinkercad in conjunction with a class challenge on designing a city 100 years in the future. Link: https://tinkercad.com/things/hRro73KY9fO
Downtown District of a Futuristic CIty dependent on a nuclear reactor

This was designed by one of my students in my 7th grade class as response to the challenge: Design a City 100 years in the Future through the lens of a current city problem. Here are the steps:
1 first students researched about cities and what makes a city;
2 they brainstormed current city problems;
  • they pick a problem, research it and typed a city description ;
  • the next step was to use tinkercad to create a 3D model of a future city that shows their solution to the issue picked ;
  • revise their 3D model to better address the problem;

description.header: Design a City 100 years in the future
description.text:
Objectives: Students will be able to model their solution to a current city problem by designing a future city. Audience: 7th graders
Preparation: Students have conducted research, brainstormed ideas and define a problem they can use in their 3d model of the city. They also practiced Tinkercad to get familiar with the 3d program.
Steps: following the engineering design process, the students worked in teams or individually to accomplish the task of creating a futuristic city that is science based.
Results: the students have accomplished their designs in tinkercad and revised them to better address the specific problem they picked in the city description part. The students have combined science and technology using a STEM approach.

Chevy Tahoe Rear Console Knob (2007)

Taking a cue from all of the lovely gears appearing on thingiverse recently, I sat down with openSCAD and figured out once and for all how to use rotate and translate together to make gears. The result is a reasonably typical music box cylinder with adjustable tooth and braille count. This version is probably not well formed for MakerBots, but could be sintered. I have an idea for a MakerBot version, but it's running late ;) \todo:
  • Accompanying worm gear (or spring, clutch, drive gear assembly?)
  • Comb
  • Base/Box

Open up the scad file and look for the rows array variable.  This array is full of zeros and ones.  Change to a one if you want to generate a braille to strike the comb at that point.  Basically, you are turning computer code into a physical binary representation, kind of like a punchcard or Jacquard loom.  Neat!

comments.author: HarlanDMii

comments.text: Also, making a makerbottable form of this would require only that instead of having straight-edged cylinders sticking out of the drum, you instead had the edge of a disc poking out. The disc's edge would jut out such that it can be printed as an overhang of less than 60%, which is easily makerbottable. The widening of individual notes/notches caused by using disc edges can be accounted for in the choice/design of the comb used.

comments.text:
@Erik My immediate notion was the same!
If we can get a cheap metal tooth-harp design up on shapeways, then the rest of the music device could be makerbottable. Once there's a script to convert music (perhaps MIDI format music, also?) into a drum, you've got printable music!

comments.text: It'd probably make sense to find an existing mass-manufactured music box that we can just replace the cylinder on, rather then reinventing that particular wheel?  (On the other hand, if we go the custom route, we can make combs that have exactly the notes we want.)

Behold! The Piper Cherokee! A staple of general aviation, the Piper Cherokee is an all-around excellent aircraft for personal ownership, flight training and air taxi. The PA-28 family of aircraft are all-metal, unpressurized, single-engine, piston-powered airplanes with low-mounted wings and tricycle landing gear. They have a single door on the copilot side, which is entered by stepping on the wing.
I began designing this in CAD around January 2016, but the rush with senior year of college shelved this project until April. Input from various members of the Piper flying community was applied as fine-tuned details on the model. I had ready access to a PA-28R-201 Arrow so the final detailing as far as engine layout and antennae configuration are based on that (N542PU). The landing gear are specific to the Arrow at the time of publishing. I have built this where changes to the variation of Cherokee can be made with quick ease. 
This model features my first attempt at moving parts connected to the model by pegs and dowels. This is experimental in nature and I cannot guarantee it's success. The support material needs to be removed from the slots to permit free movement of the controls. Once I have printed this myself I will be able to correct any errors. Any questions or issues let me know!
Version 1.1.2 - The model has been optimized for sale on my Shapeways shop. Out of it has come three models, a Cherokee, Warrior and Arrow. All of them will be uploaded here slowly over time. Enjoy!

description.text:
Behold! The E145! The ERJ 145 is part of a series of twin-engine regional jets produced by Embraer, a Brazilian aerospace company. Their direct competitor is the Bombardier CRJ series I have modeled.
This model is special, in that it is the first completed aircraft to feature actually-modeled control surfaces. Be aware that this is my first attempt, so the control surfaces do not actually move. I am currently working on creating a method that will allow movement. The usual finer details - antennae, wing rakes and pylons - are visible on the model. Any trouble? Please let me know so I can make changes and improve!
Version 1.0.9 - Revised turbine blades that were created with a new build process have replaced the lower-resolution "blades".

description.text:
The P-3 Orion is a turboprop anti-submarine aircraft developed for the United States Navy in the 60s. Lockheed based it on the L-188 Electra commercial airliner. The boom on the end of the tail is the MAD boom, which detects the change in the magnetic field of the Earth induced by a submarine. This bird is one of three to have enjoyed 50 years of continuous service. Although the P-8 Poseidon is scheduled to phase it out shortly, such has been said of newer aircraft to replace the B-52, with no result.
This model is the first I have created on request. I have a few guys in Purdue ROTC with a family background of Orion drivers, as well as a few Thingiverse members who looked to see the Orion after I finished the P-8 a few months ago. Other than a peg system to avoid glue altogether, and optional spinners and propellers, I have added wheel mounts for later addition of landing gear. Any trouble? Let me know!!
Version 1.0.4 - I have introduced a dowel plug for the fuselage and tail connection, in place of a slip-fit connector. I have decreased the taper on the ends of the dowel and narrowed the air hole. I also discovered extra polygons in the vertical stabilizer, that causes the bottom of the stabilizer to disintegrate when trying to print.

Notes: NOTE: Over the past few weeks I have noticed a few people printing the fully-assembled model in a level-attitude orientation. In my experience printing fully-assembled aircraft in the past, using this method leads to excessive use of plastic for rafts and supports, with smaller parts of the model to break off in removing these. The fully-assembled model is primarily for a preview of the finished aircraft, not the file to print. I cannot guarantee complete success with printing this way, in that I no longer use that method in favor of smoother individual parts. Print Estimate: 6hrs 29mins, at 41g
There are the dimensions I used for the design. As no hardpoints were observed on the wings and numerous reference photos I could find, I chose not to install hardpoints for missiles.

description.text:
UPDATE: To better simulate the weight of a several hundred pound engine, I have uploaded a modified nose which includes a slot to place weights post-print. Be it any high density material, it should help shift the CG forward to where the model sits upright. If you have success in this, let me know with the amount of weight you used and where you purchased it!
If you haven't looked through the rest of my model aircraft (shame on you), you may notice that I do not have any Cessna products modeled. Part of this is due to my complete lack of exposure to the Skyhawk, a shock to most of my friends in the pilot community due to it's prevalence...everywhere!! I have zero time in any high-wing. Period. 
That being said, Purdue University has received a brand-new C172 from Textron, the parent company of Cessna, as part of the Top Hawk instruction and outreach program. As a Cessna is now part of the Purdue Fleet, I feel modeling one is justified. This was a fun make, I put a lot of love and attention into it and I hope you enjoy. Any trouble? Let me know!
Version 1.0.3 - Interlocking pegs have been added to the fuselage components for easier assembly, including the propeller. If anyone would like a three-bladed prop, send me your dimensions and profile of the blade and I'll get it to you.

title: 45mm Fan Mount to 40mm TOM MK7 Heat Sink

description.text:
The 40mm fan that came with my TOM was broken.  I had a 45mm fan laying around so I made a mount to fit on the MK7 heat sink.
A little tight but works great.  Plus it sends a little air over and on the sides of the extruder stepper motor.

• Remove 40mm heat sink fan
  • Install 45mm fan on printed mount with 4xM3x16mm bolt and 4XM3 nuts
  • Install on MK7 heat sink with the 2 bolts that were on 40mm fan

description.text:
The Grumman TBF Avenger is an American torpedo bomber developed initially for the United States Navy and Marine Corps that first saw action during the Battle of Midway. Despite the loss of five of the six Avengers on its combat debut, it survived in service to become one of the outstanding torpedo bombers of World War II. These birds continued to fly well into the late 50s and 60s. 
This model was actually quite difficult to make. This is my first attempt at modeling a tailwheel aircraft. I was having quite a headache trying to carve the landing gear peg into the tail for the tailwheel. I have instead elected to have it as a glue-on option for those who would prefer the tailwheel. If you have any trouble let me know!

I wanted a more organic, smooth dickbutt, so I modeled my own. It's my own artistic interpretation, so I apologize if it's not how you picture a 3D dickbutt should look :)  I might make his arms stick out a little more, though.
Prints with a flat underside, so sticking shouldn't be a problem. However, the underside of the legs might need a support (I didn't even think about that when I made it!) I printed at both 20mm and 25mm tall and the legs didn't deform much. I'd use a rafter for these small sizes so you don't break the feet off. 
Largest I've gone is 38mm with supports for the legs and no rafter. 
Scale it at least 2x.

description.text:
This is a simple parametric holder for pens or markers, which can be customized to any size. It is printed in PETG for its combination of strength and flexibility, and adhered using 3M VHB tape which sticks quite well to most surfaces. I designed this to hold dry erase markers that I use, in conjunction with dry erase contact paper, to make mini whiteboard/note pads anywhere around the house. For example I have one on my A/C unit to keep track of when the filter was last changed. I also use it on my filament drying setup to track the weight of my dessicant (to know how much water weight is absorbed). It can be used anywhere where you want to conveniently take notes. If you are interested check out the affiliate links below for the parts used:
3M VHB Tape 1/2" Width
Dry Erase Markers
Dry Erase Contact Paper
Magnetic Whiteboard Erasers Filament Used:
eSun Semi-Transparent Blue PETG 1.75mm

comments.text: The two halves of the spool slide together. I didn't have to glue them but it could be a god idea. Screw goes through the back of the part that attaches to the pole and through the side of the reel that doesn't have the hole for attaching the handle. title: The SDvD - A DVD that holds SD cards!

description.text:
EDIT: __DO NOT DOWNLOAD CURRENT, IT DOES NOT FIT. I WILL REMODEL SOON___ This is an amazing part -- a DVD that fits SD cards in it! Just print it out and place all your SD cards in it, then put it in any laptop or desktop disk drive! (WARNING: DO NOT USE IN A MACINTOSH STYLE DISK DRIVE THAT 'sucks' THE DISK IN, THIS COULD JAM THE COMPUTER) THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS: I HAVE NOT PRINTED THE ATTACHED FILES, AND THEY ARE NOT GUARANTEED TO WORK. WASTE 2 HOURS AT YOUR OWN RISK! Got idea from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:145073
Cool part, if you have an older computer! :)

comments.text:
Some suggestions:
Make the spindle hole in the middle too big, so that the spindle won't grab it when it starts spinning when you push the tray in.
Put a Semi-circular cutout along one edge of each card hole, so that you can get your fingernail under the card when you're prying them out of the holes.

description.text: This is base guards for ELF VRDrone, specifically for beginners to resist drop or crashes. I had a pile of ZMR parts laying around and wanted to create a X-configuration frame from some of those parts. I used four arms and sandwiched them inside of a 910 Alloy X base. I also included a top plate that could probably hold a FPV camera/pod. Either configure this as a + configuration or rotate the FC +/- 45 degrees of yaw. Printed in Taulman 910 Alloy on my Printrbot Simple Metal. Designed for 5" props; with the right motors, you could probably squeeze 6" in. EDIT March 7, 2016 - I added a FPV pod for the topplate, this should protect the camera and give some new mounting options for Tx and antenna. EDIT March 12, 2016 - I finally got all the parts in to put this together and wow does it fly like a dream. Photo added with full build, parts: RCX 2205 2633's swinging 5045 props
20a Littlebees
Flip32 F3 FC running BetaFlight
Hawkeye 200mw Tx
Cheap-o IR 28mm camera Weighed in at 470 with this setup and a 1300mah battery.

title: ABS fan cover for N hotend

description.text:
Since the original solution of sliding a fan duct cover is not entirely convenient. And if you upgraded to a 40mm fan, you will have to resize the stock fan cover (which I got the model from the Raise 3D people) and it would add up to the length of the entire cover which would almost touch the heatbed (when you print ABS your heatbed would probably be more than 100 deg so even a cover made of ABS could deform due to heat) So I remixed the stock fan for it to be ABS specific i.e. no fan duct for blowing to the model.
Original model provided by Raise 3D. Version for 40mm fan attached. For all printer part, use ABS/PC to withstand heat better. Rotate the model on x-axis for 90 degree to print much better.

description.text:
It was made to be used with the original Josef Prusa's printer.
Or any other reprap with the same LCD with a 6mm circled encoder.

The Nebo Larry C work light is an awesome little device. It has a magnetic swivel pocket clip. The magnet isn't strong enough to hold it in anything other than vertical orientation. I wanted a way to use it in any orientation. I used 4 of the Neodymium 8mm magnets you can get at Home Depot. Honestly, 4 is too many. I have a hard time getting it off the surface. You can get away with adding two of the magnets. I modeled this using OnShape. Link here:

author: JINHAK

description.text: These prints allow one to install a Raspberry Pi Camera mount to their Raspberry Pi without needing to print an additional case.  This is done by mounting the pi by a block placed in the ethernet port of the Pi.  The rod used to attach the mounting pieces was 5/16" aluminum rod and the bolt at the top is an M3 x 10 mm.

Printer:

Makerfarm i3v

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: ABS Nozzle: 235 Bed: 90

I accidentally broke my gimbal in a crash. The motor holding the camera can rotate freely. There is a cable inside that can only handle a few turns. This thing can prevent that from happening, saving the gimbal. 
You need to print 2 of these.
I used thin but very strong double sided tape the stick both parts to the motor. You can choose where to block rotation by carefully choosing where to stick them.
It will influence the balance a bit, but I found no ill effect in the perfomance.

title: Cable Chain for UM2 Aluminum Extrusion

description.text: This is a remix of Robert's cable chain to fit jasonatepaint's Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer Width 2mm narrow than original for all parts and the one connected to the bed is shorter. It only have 1mm clearance to the aluminum extrusion and about 2-3mm clearance to the bed

1 x ChainBed.stl
?? x ChainSegment.stl
?? x ChainLid Since my Um2 alu extrusion is Extended size I used 14 segments and lid, it may vary from your printer size.
I am using the Heated bed upgrade from Ultimaker but it should fit the UM2 bed as well. My version is a Extended size so the chain are more than what a normal size UM2 would need

comments.text:
Hi, this is great! Any chance to have access to the source files too?
I'm looking forward the .STP of this if possible as I would love to do a remix for the UMO
comments.author: Antiklesys

comments.text: I dont have the source for this but what I did is i downloaded the STL file of Robert's cable chain in youmagine then edited it on meshmixer. Basically cutoff a portion to make the cable closed to the bed. The only edited file here is the chain bed end. If you want to give it a go just google "youmagine IRobertI Ultimaker2 Cable Chain". Not sure i should link other site links here is a good idea.
comments.author: Antiklesys

comments.text: Thanks I'll give it a go and ask Robert if he's keen on sharing the source files too :)
comments.author: jffry7

comments.text: forgot this is a remix of the thingiverse version of Robert's cable chain. Yeah he is the best person to ask
comments.author: Antiklesys

comments.text: What do you use to anchor the other end of this chain?
comments.author: captainserial

comments.text: I use to have a chain element that has an extension to screw on the alu extrusion but it needs to raise the bed clamp even higher to give clearance to the folded chain elements when bed is at the  floor. So it introduces more issue than fix. Now the bottom chain element is untethered, but it wont matter since the  bottom cable only occupies the upper left of the bottom cover while the chain parts prevents the cable going under the bed

title: Hot end fan shroud for e3d v5 with part cooling duct 40mm fan Kossel/Smartrapcore Alu

description.text:
This is a remix of the Smartfriendz hot end cooler from the smartrapcore alu printer. It is designed for the e3d v5 hot end, will fit on other printers also especially deltas, It incorporates a part cooling duct for PLA, the second object is a cover for the duct if you want to switch to printing ABS. This keeps mass low on your corexy or delta print head and allows part cooling without the added complexity of additional fans. Made a slight modification to internal profile of the duct to get more air through.
(I have tightened the leaky nozzle in the photo now) There is now a version 2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1360007 with a slide shutter to open/close (part close) the cooling duct, making it easier to switch between ABS and PLA, needs fairly high resolution to print well.

Printer:

Kossel Mini/SmartRapCore Alu

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.26

Infill:

30%

Notes: Print the fan shroud keeping the orientation I've used here, this aligns the layers perpendicular to the hot end heatsink, to prevent cracking when it is squeezed over it. It can be printed rotated 90 deg but the layers are then parallel to the heatsink and can debond when attaching the part to the printer. Supports are helpful.

I filed the external sides of the duct opening with a fine flat file to get the duct cover to fit snugly.
I am planning on making an extension to the duct for more directed airflow.
Using tinkercad

author: DjDemonD

title: DSLR Built-In Pop-Up Flash Bounce Mirror

description.text: This is another take on a bounce mirror mount for a DSLR's built-in pop-up flash. As with my other creations, I was going for simplicity in construction. There are two printed pieces, a hot shoe mounted bracket, and a mirror frame with two mounts - one mount for portrait orientation, and the other for landscape orientation. Both provide a 45-degree upward angle to a level lens (directs the flash output to the ceiling) with no further adjustments available. I fit this contraption to my Nikon D7000 and D7200. Other DSLR models ought to work as well, but I can't guarantee fit or results.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes: Print the bracket on end, with the hot shoe end down. Print the mirror frame/mount with the flat side down. No supports should be needed. (The notch in the mirror frame circumvents an apparent bug in my Cura slicer software. Without an interruption in the perimeter, it somehow just fills the hole :( )

Mirror Component This thing takes a 3" x 3" mirror. You can attach the mirror to the frame/mount with double-sided mounting pads. Mirrors are readily available in this size. One source: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004HGODQU . Another source I used for an earlier version of this thing was the Dollar Tree store... I cannibalized a chrome-finished plastic cake server spatula: https://www.dollartree.com/party-supplies/catering-supplies/Silver-Plastic-Cake-Servers-2-pc-Sets/574c584c584p342080/index.pro - cheap, light, easily obtained. Be careful when working with glass. Proceed at your own risk. Usage On my camera, I boost the flash setting by 1 EV (the maximum I can), and boost exposure by another EV as well. A white reflective surface must be directly above the camera, parallel to the camera's bottom. You will likely need to attach the mirror frame to the bracket after mounting the bracket to your camera's hot shoe. Have fun!

description.text:
This thing worked surprisingly well for me, so I figured it was worth sharing. I take a big daily vitamin, sometimes difficult to swallow, and one time it got stuck in my throat. So I break them up as best I can, and "drink" them. But a powder would be better. Searching online, I see plastic pill crushers of this design. A close fitting mortar and pestle. Some double as pill containers. Quickly whipped this up in Blender but didn't think it would work. But it does fine on these big vitamins. Pulverizes them to dust in a quarter-turn or two. Overall dimensions are near 2" x 2 1/2" (50x60mm).
50g ABS, 1 hour, 40 min. for a set, using Afinia default settings. I printed my "grinder" file upside down, as shown, to get a smooth dome on top. With the first try, fresh off the printer, there were a couple bits and hairs of red plastic in the crushed powder. Second try had none. It might be best to run some spare aspirin, vitamins or something through it, to break it in, before using it on real medication. There is pill dust left behind in the creases and layering. I wouldn't try to clean it beyond brushing the dust off. With meds that cannot be mixed, printing one for each medication is probably worth the effort. Arthritic hands may have a problem turning it, but the grips can easily be modified to accommodate that. Leave a comment or message. Metric files included.

comments.text: A word of advice:  Read the pill labels carefully and/or speak to a pharmacist and/or your doctor about crushing your pills.  I know that at least one med I'm on (a "time-release") the instructions clearly state "DO NOT CRUSH".  (I spoke to my doctor about the one I have the most trouble swallowing and asked if it would be OK to cut it.  His reply was "you can even crush it", so I've been doing that for nearly two years now.)
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Yes, good point. I was searching for general directions about using pill crushers. Hopefully there would be a list of the concerns a person might be wise to have, but I haven't found one yet, but learned a few things.
comments.author: ArizonaClark
